content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: good puzzle with tricky things to manage

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution because :joy:

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Writing interpreters is fun :)
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Okay I finished solving it without compiling opcodes. It's all executed on the fly reading one word at a time like the first BASIC interpreters (very slow).

Would you consider changing the title of the puzzle ? Forth is still used by some people, and there are many derivatives. Also every stack language or machine is related to Forth, it's not really obsolete, just unpopular for teams with untrained programmers.

Anyway, thank you for the good work.

I just love it. Forth is the best language in my opinion (https://logiqub.com).

Anyway I don't quite understand where you find the category for this puzzle. It looks like it's a code golf but I don't find the information anywhere.

Also, I am doing it the crazy way without compiling definitions. I am not quite sure I will manage to do nested branches. Unfortuntely there is no way to check wether the solution provided compiles or interpets only.

I guess it's gonna be my own fun. ;-)
the goal is too long and it is not easy to understand but fun challenge !

A minor thing :
"Very bad in fact and..." -> "Very bad, in fact, and..."

fun challenge ! Nested if was sneaky !

I think it's "otherwise push 0" for the NOT operator.

Also the integer square root test contains some tabulation. I do not know if it's done on purpose ?! and if others contain some too !

A few minor things on first read:
* "awfull" -> awful
* "transfered" -> transferred (I think, this one's to be checked)
* "crapy" -> crappy
* SUB and DIV/MOD don't say in which order the arguments are taken.^W^W^W^Wmy bad, did'nt see the SUB example
* DIV/MOD don't specify behavior for negatives. ;)
* why is IF only within DEF?
* there's no constraint on int width
* "immediatly" -> immediately

Deeper stuff:
* i assume no undefined instruction will ever be called
* is redefinition allowed?^W^W^Wscratch that, it's in the statement
* is naming a function "DEF", "END", "IF", "ELS" or "FI" allowed?

Maybe link to the original RPN puzzle?

"push 1 if this number is >= 0, otherwise push 0"
might be easier to read.

In test 11 there are two spaces here: "NZ  -40". In JS (don't ask!) split(' ') will return an empty string, which happily becomes a zero. If it is meant as a trap, well done! Otherwise, it would cause less frustration to avoid the double space :D

Puzzle looks good to me, and dealing with definitions and nested ifs was fun, thanks! I did it in the lazy way, of course :)

This puzzle can be seen as the programming extension of "Reverse Polish Notation" puzzle.

I hope the statement is clear. I discover the existence of size limit in statement text. The language is a simplified forth, with the constraint of reduced character set and to have basic instruction of 3 chars of less.

I keep the instruction set minimal, and add definition of new instruction and conditional. Loop must be done by recursion.

Reminder

*DONE* TEST : remove random tabs and multi spaces separating words
*DONE* TEST : push and test "guard value" to keep against "use and don't drop" error in basic test

Thank you for your feedback.

Yes it is easier to read, but now I only can add one char to my statement :-D

For the test, I don't mind to add trap for JS users, I'm a good guy. I'll remove those extras spaces.

But the spaces in head of a line don't hurt JS users ?

Thank you for your feedback.

Typo corrections done. I change "transferred" to "moved".

For integer size, DIV/MOD behaviour and undefined instruction, I have added a sentence in the Constraint block.

In fact no test use "MOD" function, perhaps remove this instruction.


Redefinitions are not allowed as stated ("name must not be an already defined instruction or a number."). 

For me, the fact that redefinition are not allowed, forbid to name function "DEF", ...
But perhaps this must be more explicit.

Thank you for your feedback.

ok you're right ^^

Tabulation ? normaly is only multi spaces, it is to make the code clearer.
Thank you for your feedback, I check that ;-)

Thank you for your feedback

I have set the difficulty of the puzzle to "hard" for those reasons.

As I say in a earlier comment, I have a size problem with the statement, I think I have 10 chars free now.

If you have suggestions to make the goal easier to understand, I'm interrested to hear them.

Thank you for your feedback.

In fact it is a puzzle, not a clash of Code, so it have no category (reverse/fastest/shortest).
The goal is only to write a programm that pass all the test cases.

The title of the puzzle is not to say that Forth is an obsolete language.

The "obsolete" thing is a theme to introduce a simple programming language that can be described in the puzzle statement (3300 chars).

Initially I try a prefix language, but It is a little complex to explain the function with parameter, variable name and scope.

Then I try a very minimal basic, but it don't please me and I think eval in some langage made it too easy.

Lastly I do a forth-like because is far easier to implement interessant thing as conditional and recursivity, without the burden of variable scope

To have an "obsolete" look for my language I choose a very light charset : uppercase, digit, minus sign, space and newline.
One of my idea is to encrypt that with a Radix-50 like scheme but finally it is only adding artificial difficulty.

And I think the popularity of stack machine is always high : see the JVM or the machine described by webasm specification.

Thinking about it. I know an interesting case to add. I think you only use IF ELS FI inside definitions. Why not add a test case outside a definition ?

Equality test :

SUB IF 0 ELS 1 FI OUT

Then you can put this in a defintion :

DEF EQ SUB IF 0 ELS 1 FI OUT END

It doesn't add much difficulty (you can compile an anonymous word at the top level), but some people might have problems depending on their design choices.

at the first reading I did not understand this part :
If the instruction is a number, simply put in on top of the stack.
The operations (ADD, SUB, MUL, DIV, MOD) pop the last two numbers out of the stack and push the result back on top.
For example after, 2 5 SUB 8, the stack is -3 8.

mostly : 2 5 SUB 8, the stack is -3 8 (for me 25 sub 8 = 17 at the first reading)
I did not understand the example

DEF ASQRT
  DUP 1 SWP ESTIM RS		<=== here
END

My parser failed this test cause of that ! Nothing terrible but that's why i'm asking ;)

ah ok it's not normal. Thank you to see that

EDIT : tab char removed

> For me, the fact that redefinition are not allowed, forbid to name function "DEF", 

Indeed. Scratch that too then :)
(I was getting confused by my own representation that has to find a strict distinction between user-definable functions and primitives, but in your statement there's no such issue)

Any comment on IFs being restricted to being in DEFs?

I agree that It's a little arbitrary.

It is the same "logic" as in forth : all input can be considered as an input of the user, and the "program" is really the DEF body. 

The commands outside the DEF body are as interractive command to be immediately executed, and in this context the IF/FI is not very usefull.

(OK, we can also see that as a posteriori explanation of implementation's constraint)

FWIW, my solution interprets IFs out of DEFs and it works just fine until now :D
(please don't go down the "make an otherwise great puzzle all about error detection" road!!!)
I've had a transient bug where NOT gave the right result, but didn't pop its argument. Would be nice to detect that at the "Logic" stage instead of the "IF" one as happened to me.

ah yes, push a gard value before test and check if we get this guard value.

I wait before change the test, I think the update reset all the solutions in the IDE, no ?

Much deeper stuff: is there some testing of what happens when an instruction is defined within an IF?

Back to the trivial:
* "codes than run" -> "code that runs"
* "define new instruction" -> *s
* "Line are" -> *s
* "splitted" -> split (still in there ;)
* "push back on top the result" -> "push the result back on top"
* "OVR copy" -> copies
* "exemple" -> example
* "defines the instructions" -> *instruction
* "conditional code are available" -> either "c. code is" or "conditionals are"
* "the execution continue" -> *s
* "at least 30 bits" I think you mean "less than"

And unsollicited suggestions:
* letters (uppercase) -> uppercase letters ; new line -> newline
* in most instruction semantics, use "push" when appropriate, it's widely-enough know jargon, happens to be "defined" for numbers, and reads less "childish" than "put" or "replace"
* "You can safely assume that..." -> make it a constraint instead
* the statement is close to "christmas tree syndrome", especially in dark mode. You may want to reserve the heavy-duty [[ syntax ]] for instruction definitions only and stick to {{ for the examples }}.

ah in my head nested definition are not possible.
But it is not in the statement
I think the leading spaces are fine, they are easier to notice, and easy to remove with a trim().
